summary: Louis Stokes is identified as an authorizing official on payroll authorization forms for the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA). His signature appears on documents related to the employment, salary adjustments, and termination of various HSCA staff members. The documents span from 1976 to 1978, indicating his active role during the committee's operational period. The payroll records often include details such as employee names, positions, salaries, and certifications regarding relationships with members of Congress. A recurring theme across the documents is the postponement of Social Security numbers from public release by the Assassination Records Review Board to protect personal privacy.
key_connections: HSCA staff members (e.g., Paul A. DiPaolo, James Lerer Wolf, James K. Conzelman)
significance: Louis Stokes' significance in the JFK assassination context lies in his role as an authorizing official within the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA). His authorization of payroll actions indicates his involvement in the administrative and operational aspects of the committee's work, which investigated the assassinations of President John F. Kennedy and Martin Luther King Jr.
